item.title: Desperate for a striker, N'Golo Kante compromised for Jorginho and no Plan B‚Ä¶ why Maurizio Sarri and Chelsea are searching for answers amid sub-par 'Sarriball'
item.description: MATT BARLOW: Losing twice to Spurs inside seven weeks at Wembley is no Chelsea fan's idea of a having a good time and the manager is searching for answers.
item.content:encoded:
Maurizio Sarri arrived at Chelsea promising fun and after a season of Antonio Conte's thunderous moods it was a message well received.

Eden Hazard perked up immediately as the campaign opened with an unbeaten run of 18 games in all competitions and there was even a time, albeit brief, when it seemed he might solve the Alvaro Morata puzzle.

There was lots to like about Sarriball and its eccentric creator, lost in his own world of tactical analysis, tobacco and superstition.

Then came the humbling at the hands of Tottenham in November and the impetus has faded, goals have dried up and the arm of Sarri's fun-o-meter swung back from the image of happy Hazard to the glum face of Morata.

Not a lot is wrong. Chelsea are tight at the back and can dominate in midfield, but at the very top not a lot needs to be wrong and losing twice to Spurs inside seven weeks at Wembley is no Chelsea fan's idea of a having a good time and the manager is searching for answers.


LACK OF A STRIKER

This time last year Conte, the manager who ostracised Diego Costa, was in a flap about signing a centre forward, having quickly decided Morata, the ¬£68million then-record signing, was not the answer.

Eventually, Olivier Giroud arrived but 12 months on and Sarri wants a new man up front. How he must look at Tottenham and long for Harry Kane when his own team cannot convert comfortable possession into goal threat.

Hazard through the centre denies Chelsea their best player: Hazard the wide attacker, who can score and create from the spaces he finds on the left.

Willian and Pedro, even when fit and fresh, cannot do what Hazard does in the wide areas. Callum Hudson-Odoi has caught the eye but what's the point of an old fashioned winger whipping crosses into the box if there's no-one with a goal scorer's instinct on the end?

With Hazard up front, dropping short for the ball, there is no threat in behind which, arguably, Chelsea have lacked since Costa's exit.

Conte craved a technical centre forward, who could hold up the ball, bring others into play and still offer aerial presence and weigh in with goals. So does Sarri.

Conte wanted Gonzalo Higuain. So does Sarri. Higuain is still very expensive and now 31. The deal makes little business sense.

THE MIDFIELD CONUNDRUM

NGolo Kante is a midfielder made for English football. Quick with endless stamina, a low centre of gravity and an ability to read the game.

He can cover the miles and prey on mistakes forced by the hustle and bustle. He wins the ball and moves it quickly; a turnover specialist.

He was the secret behind the Leicester miracle, helped Chelsea to the title and France to the World Cup.

He has signed a new five-year contract, thought to be worth ¬£290,000 a week and yet he does not fit smoothly into Sarri's three-man midfield.

It's hard to believe no-one saw this one coming. Jorginho is so crucial to Sarriball that it was the one summer signing he demanded before taking the job.

In this tactical system, he is the pivotal player, orchestrating the tempo and rhythm on the ball.

Kante is not a holding midfielder, he cannot play this position. He is a ball-winning midfielder and needs licence to run.

Conte soon realised he was wasted, sitting in front of the centre-halves when he switched from 4-2-3-1 to 3-4-3, the key moment in 2016-17.

Chelsea fixtures

Premier League unless stated

Saturday Newcastle (H)

January 19 Arsenal (A)

January 24 Tottenham (H) Carabao Cup semi-final, second leg

January 26/27 Sheffield Wednesday or Luton (H) FA Cup fourth round

January 30 Bournemouth (A)

February 2 Huddersfield (H)

He can operate perfectly well on the right side of Sarri's midfield trio and sometimes even look good but this role does not maximise his unique talents.

No longer does everyone leave every Chelsea game thinking: Wow, Kante‚Ä¶

With Hazard through the centre and Kante on the right, they are without their two best players. Jorginho, meanwhile, has become too easy to neutralise and has not been able to justify this decision to compromise Kante.

To get the best from Kante, the manager would have to abandon the system to which he is wed. If Chelsea truly believed in Sarriball they would have sold him in the summer to Paris Saint-Germain and used the millions to buy players who fit the system.

TURN UP THE PACE

During the early part of the season when results were going well, it was the tempo which concerned Sarri. He wanted the ball moving more quickly. He demanded one-touch and two-touch football and movement from his team.

Chelsea have high-quality players. They soon picked it up. But opponents have reacted to combat the threat.

They sit back, congest key areas, crowd Sarri's team and then try to damage them on the counter-attack.

Leicester and Wolves, quick on the break, beat them. Tottenham's penalty at Wembley came from a long ball over the top.

Losing Pedro to injury didn't help. Pedro is fast and direct and his powers may be fading but he still offers Sarri something his other strikers don't.

Also, Chelsea do not have the speed at full back when others do. Cesar Azpilicueta was ideal for Conte's back three. Marcos Alonso, a terrific wing-back. Neither fit quite so perfectly into Sarri's plans.

At the same time, fatigue is setting in, testing Sarri's desire to operate with a small core of first-team players, resisting any major squad rotation, even in the early stages of the Europa League and the Carabao Cup.

The development stages of a successful foreign coach arriving in the Premier League often follows a similar theme.

They will arrive and demand more running and intensity, then realise all this high-intensity running around in the world's most competitive league and its demanding fixture fixtures is tiring, and then complain about the gruelling schedule and demand more players.

NO PLAN B

Perhaps most noticeable in the goalless draw against Southampton when Ralph Hasenhuttl came to Stamford Bridge with a plan to bore Chelsea into submission.

Sarri's team had 72 per cent of possession and 17 shots but only six on target. The numbers were similar at Spurs in the Carabao Cup. Only Hazard's individuality lifted Chelsea above the ordinary at Watford on Boxing Day.

As more teams - especially those unwilling to go toe-to-toe at football - adopted this tactical plan, scoring has become a problem for Chelsea.

Sarri said he was satisfied up to the last 20 metres of the pitch against Saints but the last 20 metres is the important bit.

Chelsea have failed to find the net in three of their last six games and the manager is behaving as if he thinks he does not have the solution inside his squad.

Still, he keeps plugging away with his way of playing.

Liverpool finished against Manchester City with Virgil van Dijk at centre-forward. When all else fails, go long to the biggest man you have. When you're crowded out, the most obvious alternatives are set-pieces and aerial attack.

But Sarri seems so devoted to his system he has shown no hint of a willingness to change.

Maybe a new centre forward would help. Maybe Higuain can provide the technical presence and score enough goals to make a difference. Maybe it would offer Hazard a little more freedom. Maybe it would lift the manager.

Sarriball, however, is a collective philosophy. Maybe it will need more than a new centre forward before it is remodelled successfully for the Premier League.

item.title: Real Madrid's new ¬£22m signing Brahim Diaz set for debut against Leganes in Copa del Rey last 16
item.description: PETE JENSON: But he will do so from the bench because Real Madrid's disastrous league form means as few changes as possible will be made to the starting line-up for the Cup game.
item.content:encoded:
Nineteen-year-old Brahim Diaz is set to make Real Madrid his debut just 48 hours after signing his ‚Ç¨3.5million a season, six-and-a-half year contract.

But he will do so from the bench because Real Madrid's disastrous league form means as few changes as possible will be made to the starting line-up for the Cup game.

Madrid face Leganes in the last-16 of Spain's Copa del Rey and Wednesday night's home leg has taken on increased importance after the club fell 10 points behind Barcelona in the league at the weekend, losing 2-0 to Real Sociedad.


That limits coach Santiago Solari's freedom to experiment and give minutes to the former City teenager but he will feature at some point as Madrid look to find away to lift their supporters.

Solari said his appearance was 'pending paperwork' but the lowest gate of the season is expected thanks to the late kick-off (21.30 local time), the team's poor league form, and the game being a first leg.

Diaz has only trained once with his new team-mates but he has impressed them with the confident nature of his presentation on Monday and his first session on Tuesday.

He looks ready for minutes and he will get them against a Leganes side looking to repeat the feat of knocking Real Madrid out of the cup.

The defeat last season was an embarrassment to Madrid and spelled the beginning of the end for Zinedine Zidane.

The French coach began to sense that, save the big Champions League games, he was now unable to motivate the players. And the club's board - sensing the same thing - began pondering his end of season departure.

Leganes are coached by former Southampton manager Mauricio Pellegrini and have former Saints striker Guido Carillo in their ranks. But the Argentine centre-forward could be rested as Danish striker Maritn Braithwaite makes his debut on loan from Middlesbrough.

item.title: Callum Hudson-Odoi has asked Chelsea team-mate Antonio Rudiger for advice on playing in Germany as Bayern Munich close in
item.description: Talented Chelsea youngster Callum Hudson-Odoi has sought the advice of team-mate Antonio Rudiger about what it is like to play in Germany, the defender has revealed.
item.content:encoded:
Talented Chelsea youngster Callum Hudson-Odoi has sought the advice of team-mate Antonio Rudiger about what it is like to play in Germany, the defender has revealed.

Bayern Munich are continuing to pursue a move for Hudson-Odoi in January having initially seen their efforts rebuffed.

But speaking to reporters after defeat by Tottenham on Tuesday, Rudiger revealed the 18-year-old is trying to do his research on life in the Bundesliga, suggesting a move is edging closer.


'He asked me about Germany,' Rudiger said after the 1-0 Carabao Cup loss at Wembley.

'It was a general question from him. He is still young, I can advise him, but at the end of the day he decides about his future.

'You can see it from both sides. He can develop here but he can develop in Germany as well ‚Äî and don't forget Bayern Munich are also a big club. For his future, I wish him all the best but I just wish he stays with us.'

The move to Bayern is gathering pace after the Bundesliga champions matched Chelsea's ¬£35million valuation on Tuesday.

Game-time has been a big factor for the player and given the success of Englishman Jadon Sancho at Borussia Dortmund, he finds himself weighing up whether life in Germany can help kick-start his career.

So far, Hudson-Odoi has struggled for game time at Chelsea but was handed a start in the Carabao Cup semi-final on Tuesday night.

When he does play he makes an impact, as shown when he secured assists for both goals in the recent 2-0 FA Cup win over Nottingham Forest.

The ¬£58m summer arrival of Christian Pulisic from Dortmund is another factor which could push Hudson-Odoi to Bavaria but the club are keen to keep him at Stamford Bridge with boss Maurizio Sarri trying to give him more minutes in a bid to convince him to stay.

The player has just 18 months left on his deal and should he remain at the club this month, Chelsea would be under mounting pressure to cash in if he does not commit his future.

Bayern announced the signing of French right back Benjamin Pavard on Wednesday but sporting director Hasan Salihamidzic also confirmed the club's concrete interest in the Chelsea starlet.

'What I can say: we like the player and take a great interest in signing him. We'll see about the rest,' he said at the unveiling of Pavard.

'We must identify those players which can improve us. Callum has unbelievable qualities in the dribbling, he has the pace and skills. We want to sign him.'

item.title: Manchester United midfielder Ethan Hamilton in talks over Rochdale loan
item.description: Manchester United midfielder Ethan Hamilton is in talks over a loan move to League One Rochdale. The 20-year-old Scot has been a regular in Ricky Sbragia's U23 side.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United midfielder Ethan Hamilton is in talks over a loan move to League One Rochdale.

The 20-year-old Scot has been a regular in Ricky Sbragia's U23 side and has had interest from Scottish Premiership clubs.

However, United see a spell at League One Rochdale, under manager Keith Hill, as being good for his football education.


Hamilton can also play as a left wing back and has trained with United's first team.

He was called up by Jose Mourinho to replace Paul Pogba against Huddersfield Town in the squad last season when the Frenchman picked up an injury.

United coach Kieran McKenna said: 'With his attitude, it could certainly carry him very far in his career.'

Rochdale had also expressed interest in United defender Regan Poole, as have Newport County.

United, meanwhile, are discussing a move for Villarreal's 16-year-old left-back Adrian Corral.

item.title: Things go from bad to worse for injured player during Brazilian youth cup game as medical cart sent on to help runs over his foot on the pitch
item.description: Sometimes you just know when your luck is not in. In a recent Brazilian cup game, one player had the worst of fortunes, after having his foot run over by the medical cart sent on to help him.
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes you just know when your luck is not in.

In a recent Brazilian cup game, one player experienced the worst of fortunes. After going down injured, a supporting medical cart sent on field to give aid ended up running over his foot.

Trindade came up against Brasileirao giants Flamengo, and it was Bernardo on the unfortunate end of the painful malfunction.

Scroll down for video


The two sides were competing in round two of the pre-season Sao Paulo Junior Soccer Cup 2019.

Bernardo had gone down after receiving a particularly tough challenge, prompting the referee to call over the medics and the use of the driven cart-stretcher in case the player needed to be removed from play.

Upon its approach though, the cart careered far too close to the player, and drove up and over Bernardo's foot as he lay stricken on the floor.

The player could be seen instantly grabbing his foot and shouting in pain, while those around him looked puzzled.

A Copinha √© o melhor campeonato do mundo! O carrinho atropelou o jogador üòÇüòÇüòÇ pic.twitter.com/1Y9o3Q44Tf

‚Äî Humor Esportivo (@Humor_Esportivo) January 6, 2019

The nonchalant medical staff appeared unfazed by what had happened, with one even offering a wry smile to the referee after realising the situation.

Eventually, the player was assisted on to the cart, when he remained perched on the edge while it drove from the field.

Bernardo held his head in his hands as he departed. Perhaps out of pain, but most likely embarrassment.

It ended with good news for his team, however, who picked up a 1-0 victory over their rivals.

item.title: Real Madrid 'will not sack Santiago Solari this season'... unless run of bad results ends in a Bernabeu 'bloodbath'
item.description: Santiago Solari finds himself under huge pressure after Sunday's 2-0 defeat by Real Sociedad, a result which left the club fifth in La Liga and 10 points behind rivals and leaders Barcelona.
item.content:encoded:
Real Madrid are planning on sticking with manager Santiago Solari until at least the end of the season - unless there is a 'bloodbath' at the Bernabeu.

The Spaniard finds himself under huge pressure after Sunday's 2-0 defeat by Real Sociedad, a result which left the club fifth in La Liga and 10 points behind rivals and leaders Barcelona.

Solari was only named as the permanent successor to Julen Lopetegui in November, but reports had suggested he could be on his way out of Real already following last weekend's loss.


The 42-year-old, who played for the club between 2000 and 2005, has won 11 of his 15 games in charge, while also overseeing embarrassing 3-0 defeats by Eibar and CSKA Moscow.

However, Spanish radio station Cadena Cope claim that Real president Florentino Perez will keep faith in Solari unless the team's form deteriorates significantly.

According to journalist Paco Gonzalez, only a 'bloodbath' would see Solari sacked before the current campaign comes to an end in May.

It has been a difficult start to 2019 for Solari and his side after they returned from the winter break with a 2-2 draw at Villarreal, then followed it up with Sunday's home defeat against Sociedad.

Sergio Ramos and Co face Leganes in the last 16 of the Copa del Rey on Wednesday night, with Solari promising to attack in the hope of winning silverware this season.

'We will go out looking to win from the first minute and we will have to play similarly to how we did against Melilla (a 10-1 aggregate win in previous round),' he said.

'The Cup is very nice, we need to give it the attention it deserves from the opening minutes of the game.

'Tomorrow (Wednesday) we attack the Cup. We will try to win it, as we try to go out to win every game.

'We are self-critical and we have to be more decisive in the final third of the pitch.

'We're looking to win a title. It's important to be focused from the start and be more convincing in the final third.'

item.title: ‚ÄòI could watch this all day‚Äô: Chelsea fans go mad for Eden Hazard as he leaves Harry Kane on his backside with lightning quick footwork
item.description: Chelsea fans may not have been able to celebrate the result in their Carabao Cup semi-final first leg meeting with Tottenham, but that didn't stop many rejoicing in the skill of Eden Hazard.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea fans may not have been able to celebrate the result in their Carabao Cup semi-final first leg meeting with Tottenham, but that didn't stop many rejoicing in the incredible skill of star man Eden Hazard.

Spurs won the game 1-0, though Hazard was a driving force throughout and one of few positives for the Blues fans.

A dazzling piece of footwork saw Hazard leave Tottenham's main man Harry Kane slumped on the turf, and supporters quickly took to social media to express their delight and disbelief in equal measure.

Scroll down for video


'Hazard sending Kane back to White Hart lane,' wrote one fan, who shared the short clip of the Belgian leaving his counterpart for dust.

Kane had found himself in a one-on-one position with Hazard on the wing. With the odds stacked against the Spurs man, there was only going to be one winner.

Hazard caressed the ball from one foot to the other and put the England captain on the floor, effortlessly.

'I could watch this all day,' noted another fan, in awe of the winger's skill.

It wasn't the best of evenings for Chelsea though, and many fans quickly noticed Hazard becoming frustrated with his team-mates on the pitch, particularly Marcos Alonso.

The Spaniard tried and failed to find Hazard on several occasions, while a few times passing the ball to the forward when he was in the most compromising of positions.

Speculation around the future of Hazard continues to mount, with the forward endlessly linked with Spanish giants Real Madrid.

A dazzling piece of footwork saw Hazard leave Tottenham's main man Harry Kane slumped on the turf, and supporters quickly took to social media to express their delight and disbelief in equal measure.
